Recovering Labels from Local Updates in Federated Learning

Huancheng Chen â€ƒâ€ƒ Haris Vikalo
Abstract

Gradient inversion (GI) attacks present a threat to the privacy of clients in federated learning (FL) by aiming to enable reconstruction of the clientsâ€™ data from communicated model updates. A number of such techniques attempts to accelerate data recovery by first reconstructing labels of the samples used in local training. However, existing label extraction methods make strong assumptions that typically do not hold in realistic FL settings. In this paper we present a novel label recovery scheme, Recovering Labels from Local Updates (RLU), which provides near-perfect accuracy when attacking untrained (most vulnerable) models. More significantly, RLU achieves high performance even in realistic real-world settings where the clients in an FL system run multiple local epochs, train on heterogeneous data, and deploy various optimizers to minimize different objective functions. Specifically, RLU estimates labels by solving a least-square problem that emerges from the analysis of the correlation between labels of the data points used in a training round and the resulting update of the output layer. The experimental results on several datasets, architectures, and data heterogeneity scenarios demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing baselines, and helps improve quality of the reconstructed images in GI attacks in terms of both PSNR and LPIPS.

Federated Learning, Label Recovery

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), which aims to enable collaborative training of ML models while protecting privacy of the participating clients, has attracted considerable interest in privacy-sensitive fields such as healthcare and finance (Yang etÂ al., 2019). However, recent works have demonstrated vulnerability of FL systems to privacy attacks such as membership inference (Shokri etÂ al., 2017), property inference (Melis etÂ al., 2019) and gradient inversion (Zhu etÂ al., 2019). In particular, gradient inversion methods have been shown capable of reconstructing private training data given the gradients computed during local training. The milestone work, Deep Leakage from Gradient (DLG) (Zhu etÂ al., 2019), minimizes the difference between simulated and true gradients to extract data and the corresponding labels belonging to FL clients training a model for a classification task. However, DLG does not perform well in settings where the training batch size is large and the data resolution is high, since in such scenarios the joint optimization of data and the corresponding labels becomes challenging. A subsequent study, iDLG (Zhao etÂ al., 2020), presents an analytical method for the recovery of ground-truth labels from the gradients by exploiting a relationship between the labels and the signs of the gradients. GradInversion (Yin etÂ al., 2021) takes a step further by exploiting a relationship between labels and the magnitudes of gradient in the output layer to perfectly restore labels of the samples used in the considered training round, and facilitates high-resolution reconstruction of data in a batch with as many as 48 samples. Unfortunately, this method assumes no repeated labels in the batch, which is unrealistic in real-world settings. Recently, iRLG (Ma etÂ al., 2023) attempted to address the limitations of GradInversion, enabling recovery of potentially repeated labels in a batch by utilizing gradients computed using a randomly initialized untrained model. However, the performance of iRLG drastically deteriorates as the modelâ€™s accuracy improves.

The above label recovery methods either: (1) assume no repeated labels in a batch; (2) use non-negative network activation functions; or (3) perform well only on untrained models. They further assume that each client in an FL system runs only a single epoch when updating its local model, while the more practical settings with multiple epochs of local training are not considered. Moreover, these studies are limited to the scenarios where a server collects gradients and do not apply to the standard FL setting where the server collects model updates rather than the gradients.

Aiming to address the aforementioned limitations of the prior work, in this paper we propose a novel method for label recovery, Recovering Labels from Local Updates (RLU). We start by analyzing correlations between local updates of the output layer and the ground-truth labels of data samples in training batches for several frequently used FL algorithms. These correlations, along with the expected value of the â€œerroneous confidenceâ€ (i.e., the level of confidence when making erroneous decisions) evaluated on a small auxiliary dataset, are then used to recover the labels. As local training unfolds across multiple epochs, distribution of the previously mentioned â€œerroneous confidenceâ€ undergoes changes which the server cannot access. Simulating an underlying dynamical model helps estimate how this distribution evolves across training epochs; the obtained estimates of intermediate distributions are then utilized to help achieve notable enhancement in the accuracy of label recovery. The effectiveness of RLU is demonstrated in extensive experiments involving several FL algorithms and various model architectures on SVHN, CIFAR10, CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet datasets. In all the considered settings, RLU outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on both untrained and well-trained models. The main contributions of the paper are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose a general analytical method that enables the server in an FL system to recover labels of the points used by clients in local training; the proposed method applies to various FL algorithms and makes no assumptions regarding the activation function or batch label composition.

  • â€¢

    To allow accurate label recovery in FL systems where clients train across multiple epochs, we simulate the evolution of the model through the epochs via a Monte Carlo method that updates the â€œerroneous confidenceâ€ characterizing the correlation between local updates and training data labels.

  • â€¢

    To evaluate the proposed label recovery method, we conduct comprehensive benchmarking experiments across a number of FL settings where we vary the level of data heterogeneity, model architectures and local objective functions.

2 Preliminary and Related Work

Federated Learning. The classical FL algorithm, FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), enables Kğ¾K clients to collaboratively train global model without sharing their private data ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}. In FedAvg, the server initializes training round tğ‘¡t by broadcasting global model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to the clients. Client kğ‘˜k updates its local model by running a gradient descent procedure on its (private) local data; the server then collects updated local models ğœ½k(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} from the clients and averages them to form a new global model,

ğœ½(t+1)=âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹ğœ½k(t),superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}, (1)

where pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} denotes the weight assigned to client kğ‘˜k. Since the training is initialized by broadcasting global model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to the clients, local updates are computed as Î”â€‹ğœ½k(t)=ğœ½k(t)âˆ’ğœ½(t)Î”subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}. It is worth pointing out that in FL algorithms other than FedAvg, Î”â€‹ğœ½k(t)Î”subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} is not necessarily proportional to the gradients âˆ‡ğœ½k(t)âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k}. We discuss properties of local updates in Section 3.3.

Gradients Inversion Attack. DLG (Zhu etÂ al., 2019) is the first optimization-based method for reconstructing training data given the gradients âˆ‡ğœ½âˆ‡ğœ½\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta} and model ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}. More specifically, DLG minimizes the difference between simulated and ground-truth gradients,

ğ±â‹†,ğ²â‹†=argâ€‹minğ±â€²,ğ²â€²â¡â€–âˆ‡ğœ½â„’taskâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ±â€²,ğ²â€²)âˆ’âˆ‡ğœ½â€–2.superscriptğ±â‹†superscriptğ²â‹†argsubscriptsuperscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğœ½subscriptâ„’taskğœ½superscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²âˆ‡ğœ½2\mathbf{x}^{\star},\mathbf{y}^{\star}=\text{arg}\min_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime}}\left\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{task}}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime})-\nabla\boldsymbol{\theta}\right\|^{2}. (2)

Follow-up studies (Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021) introduced total variation and group consistency regularization to the objective of the gradient inversion optimization, enabling high reconstruction performance on ImageNet (Deng etÂ al., 2009). Recently, a number of works (Jeon etÂ al., 2021; Fang etÂ al., 2023; Zhang etÂ al., 2023) leveraged pre-trained generative models to improve the gradient inversion attack and achieve state-of-the-art performance with batch size set to 323232. However, these schemes assume knowing the ground-truth labels ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y} in the batch â€“ an unrealistic assumption that significantly accelerates the search for the optimal data ğ±â‹†superscriptğ±â‹†\mathbf{x}^{\star}.

Label Recovery Attack. To improve the performance of an attack on gradients computed using samples coming from a relatively large batch, a series of studies (Zhao etÂ al., 2020; Yin etÂ al., 2021; Dang etÂ al., 2021; Wainakh etÂ al., 2021; Geng etÂ al., 2021; Ma etÂ al., 2023) proposed various analytical approaches to recovering labels ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y} prior to solving the optimization over ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. However, all these methods suffer limitations that restrict their practical feasibility. GradInversion (Yin etÂ al., 2021) assumes there are no repeated labels in a batch; RLG (Dang etÂ al., 2021) can only recover class-wise labels but not instance-wise labels; LLG (Wainakh etÂ al., 2021) and ZLG (Geng etÂ al., 2021) require non-negative activation functions; iRLG (Ma etÂ al., 2023) performs well only on randomly initialized untrained models. Moreover, these methods primarily focus on FedAvg and generally provide little if any discussion of other FL algorithms.

3 Methodology

3.1 Problem Settings

We consider multi-class classification models trained in FL settings where an honest-but-curious (HBC) server aims to recover ground-truth labels of the training samples using local updates Î”â€‹ğœ½k(t)Î”subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} collected from clients while following a standard FL training procedure. The HBC server knows the batch size, number of local epochs and learning rate used by the clients but has no information about local data distribution. We assume each local model is trained by minimizing the cross-entropy (CE) loss

3.2 Label Recovery from Local Updates (RLU)

Assumption 3.1.

The existing methods that perform well only on untrained models operate under the assumption ğn=ğŸsubscriptğğ‘›0\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}=\mathbf{0}, which does not hold for well-trained models. Experimental results that empirically verify AssumptionÂ 3.1 are provided in AppendixÂ B.3.

3.2.2 Multiple Epochs of Local Training

To reduce communication bandwidth, clients in FL typically update their local models over multiple epochs (with multiple batches of data), as illustrated in Eq.Â 5. 3.3 FL schemes beyond FedAvg and SGD

The prior works on GI attacks in FL focused on FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), where local training pursues minimization of the CE loss, â„’cesubscriptâ„’ce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}. Deterioration of the performance of FedAvg observed in non-i.i.d. settings motivated a number of studies (Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Acar etÂ al., 2021; Gao etÂ al., 2022; Chen etÂ al., 2023; Chen & Vikalo, 2023a, b) that address the challenge of data heterogeneity by introducing various regularization terms to the local objective function. In particular, those methods consider objectives that are combination of the empirical risk and a regularizer, i.e.,

â„’local=â„’ce+â„’regularizer.subscriptâ„’localsubscriptâ„’cesubscriptâ„’regularizer\mathcal{L}_{\text{local}}=\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}+\mathcal{L}_{\text{regularizer}}. (15)

For such objectives, the local updates of the bias collected by a server are not proportional to the gradients of â„’cesubscriptâ„’ce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}, adversely affecting the efficacy of the existing methods that attempt to recover labels from gradients. Furthermore, the existing label recovery methods assume that the local models are updated using SGD optimizers. When optimizers other than SGD are used, local updates are generally not proportional to the gradients of â„’cesubscriptâ„’ce\mathcal{L}_{\text{ce}}. To explore such settings, we analyze the expectation of local updates in several milestone non-i.i.d. FL schemes and consider two well-known variants of SGD (Ruder, 2016), SGD with momentum (SGDm) and Nesterov accelerated gradient method (NAG). To accommodate these more general cases, we rephrase the expectation of the jğ‘—j-th component of the local update of bias ğ”¼â€‹[Î”â€‹ğ›j(t)]ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”superscriptsubscriptğ›ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t)}\right] in global round tğ‘¡t as

Î·|â„¬|â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1mÏ(Ï„)â€‹(Nj(t,Ï„)â€‹âˆ‘nâ‰ jğ’®j,n(t,Ï„)âˆ’âˆ‘nâ‰ jNn(t,Ï„)â€‹ğ’®n,j(t,Ï„))âˆ’ğ¡j(t),ğœ‚â„¬superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘šsuperscriptğœŒğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{B}|}\sum_{\tau=1}^{m}\rho^{(\tau)}\left(N_{j}^{(t,\tau)}\sum_{n\not=j}\mathcal{S}_{j,n}^{(t,\tau)}-\sum_{n\not=j}N_{n}^{(t,\tau)}\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)}\right)-\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)}, (16)

where Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} is a constant that depends on hyper-parameters used by different methods and remains constant across global rounds, and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} is a term capturing historical training information (past local updates). We summarize the values of Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} for different FL schemes in TableÂ 1 (derivations provided in Appendix A.4-A.9). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that studies label recovery attacks in FL schemes beyond FedAvg. In FL schemes that utilize only the gradient information computed in the current global round (e.g., FedAvg and FedProx) ğ¡jt=ğŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}=\mathbf{0}, while for the schemes that also rely on the past gradient information (Scaffold, FedDyn and FedDC) ğ¡jtâ‰ ğŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}\not=\mathbf{0}. In any case, Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} are known to the server and may potentially be used for label recovery attacks. In our work, we rely on the procedure for label recovery from local updates discussed in the previous section to run RLU attacks on different FL schemes where Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡jtsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t} vary from one scheme to another according to TableÂ 1.

4 Experiments

4.1 Setups

We evaluate the performance of RLU on a classification task using a variety of model architectures including LeNet-5 (LeCun etÂ al., 1998), VGG-16 (Simonyan & Zisserman, 2014) and ResNet-50 (He etÂ al., 2016), and four benchmark datasets including SVHN (Netzer etÂ al., 2011), CIFAR10, CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015). Throughout these experiments we employ a number of activation functions including ReLU, Tanh, ELU (Clevert etÂ al., 2015), SELU (Klambauer etÂ al., 2017) and SiLU (Elfwing etÂ al., 2018) to further evaluate robustness of our proposed method. To simulate diverse FL scenarios, we follow the strategy in (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019) and utilize Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha, controlling the level of data heterogeneity across 101010 data partitions owned by 10 clients. Unless specified otherwise, the models are trained using SGD optimizers. The auxiliary dataset ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} contains 100100100 samples per class. Further experimental details are provided in Appendix B.2.

4.2 Baselines and Evaluation Metrics

We compare our proposed RLU to three state-of-the-art methods: LLG (Wainakh etÂ al., 2021), ZLG (Geng etÂ al., 2021) and iRLG (Ma etÂ al., 2023), all capable of recovering repeated labels in a batch. For fairness, we compare RLU to LLG+ and ZLG+; the latter two utilize the same auxiliary dataset ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} as RLU to achieve improved performance. Following the strategy of iRLG, we quantify the performance of a label recovery attack using two metrics: (1) class-level accuracy (cAcc): the proportion of correctly recovered classes; (2) instance-level accuracy (iAcc): the proportion of correctly recovered labels. Details of computing cAcc and iAcc are provided in AppendixÂ B.4. We recover batch labels from the local updates computed on clientsâ€™ local dataset and report the average cAcc and iAcc.

4.3 Attack on Untrained Models

A randomly initialized untrained model may be extremely vulnerable to label recovery attacks; for instance, if the server knows how the training is initialized, it does not even need an auxiliary data set to infer the parameters (e.g., ğnsubscriptğğ‘›\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}) used in the attack. To compare the performance of baseline methods with that of RLU, we conduct comprehensive experiments on untrained models across various architectures, datasets, batch-sizes and activation functions. The results, reported in TableÂ 2, demonstrate that RLU outperforms the baselines in all settings. When local training consists of a single epoch, RLU achieves near-perfect accuracy across the board in terms of both cAcc and iAcc; iRLG is a close second, outperforming other baselines. Since LLG+ assumes non-negative activation functions, its performance deteriorates significantly with Tanh and SELU. On Tiny-ImageNet, ZLG+ performs the worst among the four methods, achieving under 70%percent7070\% iAcc.

When the clients run m=10ğ‘š10m=10 local epochs, performance of all methods deteriorates (as expected based on the discussion in Section 3.2.2). Nevertheless, the results in TableÂ 2 show that RLU still outperforms the baselines, maintaining at least 84%percent8484\% cACC and 90%percent9090\% iAcc on all datasets, architectures and activation functions. While iRLG maintains solid performance on SVHN and Tiny-ImageNet, it performs significantly worse on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 (iAcc falls below 70%percent7070\%, cAcc drops below 50%percent5050\%). The results of LLG+ follow the same pattern exhibited in single epoch settings, while ZLG+ experiences significant performance deterioration on SVHN. For consistency and a comparison with the results in TableÂ 2, unless stated otherwise, in the remainder of this section the number of local epochs mğ‘šm is set to 101010.

4.4 Attack on Trained Models

Since the accuracy of the global model improves as the training proceeds, comparing methods in terms of attacks on untrained model becomes no longer meaningful. As discussed in Section 3.2, distribution of output logits depends on the accuracy of the model which is parameterized by mean ğnsubscriptğğ‘›\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n} and covariance ğšºnsubscriptğšºğ‘›\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n}. When the model becomes highly accurate, magnitudes of local gradients (updates) start vanishing; this, in turn, causes high sensitivity to noise and a large error in estimating the labels. All of the methods in TableÂ 2 experience performance deterioration as the model accuracy increases. To compare their robustness, we conduct extensive experiments and evaluate performance of different attack methods at different stages of training. As shown in Fig.Â 1, RLU outperforms the baselines at all training stages, achieving 80%percent8080\% iAcc when the model accuracy reaches 80%percent8080\%. For the global model achieving 90%percent9090\% training accuracy, iAcc of iRLG reaches 75.6%percent75.675.6\%, 83.3%percent83.383.3\% and 72.6%percent72.672.6\% on SVHN, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The iAcc of ZLG+ is 33.3%percent33.333.3\%, 21.1%percent21.121.1\% and 30.1%percent30.130.1\% lower than RLUâ€™s, while iRLGâ€™s trails RLU by 16.3%percent16.316.3\%, 17.3%percent17.317.3\% and 23.9%percent23.923.9\% on these three datasets, respectively. The iAcc performance of LLG+ is better than that of other prior methods but still falls significantly behind RLUâ€™s.

4.5 Effect of Data Heterogeneity

Data heterogeneity is one the main challenges in real-world applications of federated learning. Prior works on label reconstruction evaluated their proposed methods on i.i.d. data, but the evaluation on non-i.i.d. data has remained largely unexplored. To this end, we benchmark the methods considered in this paper on CIFAR10 data partitions generated for varied values of Î±={0.05,0.1,0.5,1,5}ğ›¼0.050.10.515\alpha=\{0.05,0.1,0.5,1,5\} (smaller Î±ğ›¼\alpha corresponds to higher level of heterogeneity). We visualize the generated data partitions in Appendix B.5. TableÂ LABEL:table3 shows that iAcc of the three baselines monotonically decreases with the level of data heterogeneity. On the other hand, RLU demonstrate a great degree of robustness as it maintains high iAcc across the board; in particular, RLU achieves 93%percent9393\% or higher instance-level accuracy in all settings, including at the highest level of data heterogeneity (Î±=0.05ğ›¼0.05\alpha=0.05).

4.6 Effect of the Size of Auxiliary Dataset ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}

As previously discussed, RLU needs an auxiliary dataset ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} to estimate moments of the output logits distribution. In the benchmarking experiments presented thus far, we used 100100100 samples for each class in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. To analyze the effect of the size of auxiliary dataset on the performance of RLU, we conduct 444 sets of experiments that utilize 444 auxiliary datasets with: (1) 555 samples per class; (2) 101010 samples per class; (3) 505050 samples per class; and (4) 100100100 samples per class. As shown in Fig.Â 2, there appears to be no significant performance degradation due to reduction of the auxiliary data set size. When using the smallest among the auxiliary sets, on SVHN and Tiny the proposed RLU achieves performance close to the baseline. The largest performance gap is on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, and even there the gap is only 2.4%percent2.42.4\% and 3.1%percent3.13.1\%, respectively. Therefore, RLU exhibits robustness with respect to the variations in the size of the auxiliary data set used by the server.

4.7 Attacks on Different FL Schemes

To the best of our knowledge, prior works evaluate their methods only on FedAvg. While FedAvg is indeed the oldest and perhaps the most widely used FL scheme, a number of other FL schemes has grown to prominence yet remains largely unexplored in the context of label recovery. As discussed in Section 3.3, we provide a framework to conduct label recovery attacks on several regularization-based FL schemes that may be using various optimizers. TableÂ 4 shows the superior performance of RLU in the experiments on FedProx and SGDm. As can be seen from the table, in the experiments where Î»=0.5ğœ†0.5\lambda=0.5 and Î³=0.1ğ›¾0.1\gamma=0.1 (which leads to Ï(Ï„)â‰ˆ1superscriptğœŒğœ1\rho^{(\tau)}\approx 1), the three baselines achieve performance similar to that in their attacks on FedAvg. However, as Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} deviates from 111 when Î»=5ğœ†5\lambda=5 and Î³=0.9ğ›¾0.9\gamma=0.9, performance of the baselines severely deteriorates while RLU maintain its iAcc of at least 88%percent8888\%.

4.8 Improved Gradient Inversion Attacks with RLU

The outstanding performance of RLU on label recovery can improve the gradient inversion attacks in federated learning. In the prior work IG (Geiping etÂ al., 2020), an HBC server performs joint optimization of the reconstructed labels ğ²â€²superscriptğ²â€²\mathbf{y}^{\prime} and images ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, which typically results in slow convergence and poor quality of the reconstructed images. We conduct gradients inversion attack experiments on CIFAR10, where we use RLU to estimate labels ğ²â€²superscriptğ²â€²\mathbf{y}^{\prime} from local updates and only optimize the reconstructed images ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime} according to Eq. 2. To quantitatively characterize the quality of reconstructed images, we compute the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and the learned perceptual image patch similarity (LPIPS) (Zhang etÂ al., 2018) of the reconstructed images in each batch. As illustrated in Fig. 3, images reconstructed with the help of RLU have higher PSNR and lower LPIPS, indicating smaller distance to the original images.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we studied label recovery attacks on federated learning systems in which clients send their local model updates to the server for aggregation. We developed RLU, a novel label recovery method which solves a least-square problem constructed by examining the correlation between the number of samples of each label type and local updates of the output layer. We extended the proposed framework to real-world scenarios involving well-trained models, multiple local epochs, high levels of data heterogeneity and various local objective functions, and provided theoretical analysis of RLU in different FL schemes. Comprehensive experiments on four datasets, three model architectures and six activation functions demonstrate consistently high accuracy, robustness and universality of RLU. Moreover, gradients inversion attack experiments illustrate that utilizing RLU may significantly improve quality of the reconstructed data in term of two widely-used metrics, PSNR and LPIPS. Future work will include exploring defense mechanism that may help ameliorate safety concerns caused by RLU.

Appendix B Experimental Details

B.1 Comparison with Prior Works

We qualitatively summarize capabilities of the state-of-the-art label recovery methods in TableÂ 5. A check mark (âœ”) indicates that a method is suitable for a given setting while the cross mark (âœ—) indicates that it is not. As the table indicates, RLU is capable of operating in a variety of scenarios.

B.2 Experimental Settings

B.2.1 General Settings

We used Pytorch (Paszke etÂ al., 2019) to implement all the described experiments. In the experiments involving SVHN, the clients used LeNetÂ (LeCun etÂ al., 1998), a convolutional neural network with 161616 convolution layers and 5Ã—5555\times 5 kernel, as the classifier. The batch size was set to 323232 in all experiments on SVHN. In the experiments involving CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, the clients trained Vgg-16 (Simonyan & Zisserman, 2014) with different scales of convolution kernel as the classifier. The batch size was set to 646464 and 256256256 in the experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. In the experiments involving Tiny-ImageNet, the clients learned a standard ResNet-50 (He etÂ al., 2016) where the batch size was set to 256256256. The number of clients was set to 101010 across all the experiments.

B.2.2 Settings of the Experiments in TableÂ 2

The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta for the SGD optimizer was set to 0.010.010.01 in all experiments reported in TableÂ 2. In order to obtain high level of data heterogeneity, we set the concentration parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha to 0.50.50.5 in the experiments on SVHN and CIFAR10; in the experiments on CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet, this parameter was set to 0.10.10.1. There are two groups of experiments in TableÂ 2; in one the number of local epochs mğ‘šm was set to 111, while in the other it was set to 101010. For the experiments involving multiple local epochs, the number of iterations Tğ‘‡T in Alg.Â 2 was set to 101010.

B.2.3 Settings of the Experiments in TableÂ LABEL:table3

Here we explored the effect of data heterogeneity controlled by varying the concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha from 0.050.050.05 to 555. For a fair comparison, we set the number of local epochs to m=10ğ‘š10m=10; other settings were identical to the settings in TableÂ 2.

B.2.4 Settings of the Experiments in TableÂ 4, FigureÂ 1 and FigureÂ 2

Similar to TableÂ 2 and TableÂ LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs mğ‘šm to 101010 in all experiments reported in TableÂ 4, FigureÂ 1 and FigureÂ 2. The concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

B.2.5 Settings of the Experiments in Gradients Inversion Attack

We conducted gradients inversion attack on the training set of CIFAR10 with an untrained ResNet32 model. We follow the strategy in IG (Geiping etÂ al., 2020), using cosine similarity as the distance between ground-truth gradients and the estimated gradients computed using reconstructed images and labels. The batch size was set to 999 and the number of iterations for optimizing the reconstructed images and labels was set to 240002400024000. We used Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014) optimizer and set the learning rate to 0.10.10.1. We also added the total variation regularization (Yin etÂ al., 2021) to the objective function to create more realistic images with a weight scalar 0.20.20.2.

B.3 Empirical Validation of Assumption 3.1

To verify Assumption 3.1, we perform inference on the training set of SVHN and CIFAR10 using the global model across different training rounds. We collect the jğ‘—j-th component of the output logits for the samples with label nğ‘›n, and organize them into 100100100 bins to generate histograms. In each histogram, x-axis indicates the values of the jğ‘—j-th component of the output logits while the values on y-axis indicate the corresponding number of samples. As shown in FiguresÂ 4 and 7, means ğn,jsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j} of the randomly initialized global model are close to 00 regardless of their sign. As the training accuracy of the global model improves, the means ğj,jsubscriptğğ‘—ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\mu}_{j,j} increase to larger positive values while ğn,jâ€‹(nâ‰ j)subscriptğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘—\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}(n\not=j) decreases to negative values, as shown in Figures 4-9.

B.4 Evaluation Metrics

We follow the strategy in iRLG (Ma etÂ al., 2023), evaluating all methods in terms of class-level accuracy (cAcc) and instance-level accuracy (iAcc). Specifically, cAcc indicates the proportion of correctly recovered classes while iAcc indicates the proportion of correctly recovered labels. Suppose ğ²csubscriptğ²ğ‘\mathbf{y}_{c} denotes the ground-truth classes that appear in the batches while ğ²^csubscript^ğ²ğ‘\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{c} denotes the estimated classes; then cAcc can be computed as

where Nğ‘N is the total number of classes. Similarly, suppose ğ²isubscriptğ²ğ‘–\mathbf{y}_{i} denotes the ground-truth labels in the batches while ğ²^isubscript^ğ²ğ‘–\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i} denotes estimated labels; then iAcc can be computed as

We follow the strategy in (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019), utilizing Dirichlet distribution to generate heterogeneous data partitions from the original datasets. Specifically, we assign different proportions ğ©k(j)superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘˜ğ‘—\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(j)} of samples with label jğ‘—j in the local dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} to Kğ¾K clients according to

Nk(j)=ğ©k(j)âˆ‘iKğ©i(j)â€‹N(j),superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘ğ‘—N_{k}^{(j)}=\frac{\mathbf{p}_{k}^{(j)}}{\sum_{i}^{K}\mathbf{p}_{i}^{(j)}}N^{(j)}, (94)

Figures 10 and 11 show the class distribution of clientsâ€™ local dataset by color-coding the number of samples: the darker the color, the larger the number of samples with the corresponding label. Appendix C Algorithms

C.1 RLU Algorithm

In this section, we formalize the RLU algorithm as Alg.1. In the standard paradigm in federated learning, the server broadcasts the global model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} to selected clients; these clients then initialize their local model ğœ½k(t)superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)} to start local training. After mğ‘šm local epochs, each client kğ‘˜k computes the local update Î”â€‹ğœ½k(t)=ğœ½k(t)âˆ’ğœ½(t)Î”superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\Delta\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} including Î”â€‹ğ–k(t)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\Delta\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(t)} and Î”â€‹ğ›k(t)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\Delta\mathbf{b}_{k}^{(t)}. For convenience, we omit the subscript kğ‘˜k in Î”â€‹ğ–k(t)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\Delta\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(t)} and Î”â€‹ğ›k(t)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ›ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\Delta\mathbf{b}_{k}^{(t)} in Alg.1. According to the formulated problem in Section 3.1, the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta in local training is known by the server. While preparing to conduct label recovery attack, the server estimates ğn(t),Î£n(t),ğ’®n,j(t),ğn,j(t+1),Î£n(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘›ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘›ğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}^{(t)},\Sigma_{n}^{(t)},\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t+1)},\Sigma_{n}^{(t+1)}, and ğ’®n,j(t+1),âˆ€n,jâˆˆ[N]superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡1for-allğ‘›ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t+1)},\forall n,j\in[N] via Monte Carlo method according to Eq.Â 8 with the global model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}, updated local model ğœ½k(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}_{k} and the auxiliary dataset ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. If m=1ğ‘š1m=1, the server simply solves the least-squares problem described in Eq.Â 10. If m>1ğ‘š1m>1, the server first solves the least-squares problem using coefficients computed as the mean of ğ’®n,j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)} and ğ’®n,j(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡1\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t+1)} to obtain a crude estimate. Then the server conducts posterior search (Alg.Â 2) to adjust the estimated N(t)superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N^{(t)} as discussed in Section 3.2.2.

C.2 Posterior Search Algorithm

In Alg.Â 2, we simulated the dynamics of ğn(t)superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}^{(t)} during local training. First, the server estimates average embedded signal ğÂ¯Â¯ğ\bar{\mathbf{e}} according to Eq.Â 14. Using the crude estimates of N(t)superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N^{(t)} and ğ’®n,j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathcal{S}_{n,j}^{(t)} as inputs, the server computes Î”â€‹ğ›j(t,Ï„)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(t,\tau)} according to Eq.Â 12. Subsequently, the server computes Î”â€‹ğn,j(t,Ï„)Î”superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ\Delta\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau)} using ğÂ¯Â¯ğ\bar{\mathbf{e}}, and then estimates ğ^n,j(t,Ï„+1)superscriptsubscript^ğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}. Recursively, repeating the procedure, the server finally obtains ğ^n,j(t,Ï„+1)superscriptsubscript^ğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}. Based on the difference between ğ^n,j(t,Ï„+1)superscriptsubscript^ğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ1\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)} and ğn,j(t,Ï„+1)superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğœ1\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n,j}^{(t,\tau+1)}, the server can calibrate/improve estimated N(t)superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡N^{(t)}.
